III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Compliance with the child protection law
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12214
Section • (1) An agency shall comply with the child protection law,
Description 1975 PA 238, MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Three foster youth were placed in a foster home from May 2022-
September 2023. During this period, the children went to 177
medical appointments, diagnosed with several ailments, and
endured medical procedures and surgeries. One of the foster
parents has extensive mental health history and there is a concern
for Munchausen by Proxy. Since the youth have moved, the
youth's medical problems have not persisted or improved. Second
opinions were sought from new doctors and these medical
professionals report no concerns for the children. The foster care
case managers were aware of these concerns but failed to report
them given all of the information at hand.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on July 16, 2024.
There was no additional information to add.
Foster Parent 1 & Foster Parent 2 were interviewed face to
face by DHHS Worker on June 21, 2024. Their attorney was
present via telephone and advised them not to answer any
questions.
Private Agency Foster Care Chief Administrator (PAFC CA)
was interviewed via telephone on June 28, 2024. She stated
she first became aware of Foster Parent 1 & 2 when her staff
alerted her there was an issue. Youth A, B and C were placed in
Foster Parent 1 & 2’s home through a borrowed bed placement
and the agency was not aware of the extent of the mental health
history since none of the inpatient mental health records were
2

included in the initial home study evaluation that is received and
reviewed prior to a borrowed bed placement.
Staff informed her Youth A, B and C needed to be moved and
there were lengthy discussions due to how long the kids had been
in the foster parents’ home. PAFC CA stated it was during the
adoption process the concerns escalated due to receipt of multiple
inpatient mental health records for Foster Parent 1 and the large
number of medical appointments the children were subjected to,
some of which the agency was not aware of.
PAFC CA stated the agency discussed the concerns of
Munchausen Proxy internally, regarding Foster Parent 1 & 2. She
clarified they were concerned that it was Munchausen by Proxy,
but they did not have a doctor that would support this concern.
She clarified none of the medical providers involved with Youth A,
Youth B and Youth C, reported any concern but this concern
wasn’t discussed with the doctor’s either. There wasn’t anything to
call into Centralized Intake because they didn’t have a doctor
stating Youth A, B or C were taken to medical appointments or
procedures that weren’t needed.
She stated they were torn because the kids had been in the
placement for a long time and there were many discussions
regarding disrupting the placement and adoption. The agency
contacted Michigan Children’s Institute (MCI) with their concerns.
MCI supported the agency and their concerns and agreed it was
in the best interest of the children to remove them from Foster
Parent 1 & 2.
PAFC Program Manager (PAFC PM) was interviewed via
telephone on July 2, 2024. She stated she was first made aware
of concerns regarding Youth A, B and C in the foster parent’s
placement after termination of parental rights took place in March
2023 and the adoption worker started assessing the home. This
included reviewing the file and documents and conducting visits.
The PAFC Adoption Worker didn’t feel the 3130A that was
completed on Foster Parent 1 & 2 was adequate, specifically
regarding the mental health history.
There were internal discussions regarding the concerns. The
consensus was they would address the concerns with the
licensing agency and go from there. However, the meetings did
not go well. The licensing agency was defensive of Foster Parent
1 and 2 and did not seem to want to open a special evaluation to
3

investigate or address their concerns. She stated prior to one of
the meetings, they were asked by the licensing agency for their
concerns in writing and provided a written response about 15
minutes before the meeting started. During the meeting there was
limited dialogue, and the licensing agency made them feel as
though the concerns were blown out of proportion.
PAFC PM stated they were concerned about the excessive
number of medical appointments and questioned the situation.
There was additional information that their office obtained after the
children were moved in September 2023. Specifically new medical
providers that were not in agreement with previously reported
concerns. They are currently placed with relatives and current
medical providers are stating there are a number of
services/appointments the children do not need. They had strong
suspicions, but they did not have any medical professionals that
stated the children were going to too many appointments.
PAFC Adoption Worker (PAFC AW) was interviewed via video
conference on July 3, 2024. She is assigned to the case for
Youth A, B and C. She began assessing Foster Parent 1 & 2 for
the adoption process in March 2023. She indicated they signed
the intent to adopt not long after she was assigned the case, and
she began her assessment not long after. She stated Foster
Parents 1 & 2 are licensed through another agency and had been
a borrowed bed placement for their office. She requested their
home study and had heard there had been some concerns with
the number of appointments Foster Parents 1 & 2 took the
children to.
Upon being assigned to the case PAFC FC Supervisor 2 had
informed her Youth A, B & C go to a lot of appointments and there
were issues with Foster Parent 1 & 2 notifying the agency after the
fact and sometimes not informing them at all. She stated PAFC
FC Supervisor 2 had indicated there had also been some
discussions with Foster Parents 1 & 2 regarding the need for
some of the appointments and provided an example of problem
solving when the children have a cold, such as do the children
need to be seen by a doctor or could a visit to the doctor wait a
day or two to see if it clears up. PAFC AW obtained access to the
children’s patient portals at Cherry Health. Foster Parent 1 & 2
had requested access and were told by the PAFC not to request
access but went and obtained access anyway. Once PAFC AW
had access to the patient portals is when the agency realized how
often the children were going to the doctor; especially Youth C
4

who had over 200 appointments since being placed with Foster
Parent 1 & 2 for less than one year.
In reviewing the initial home study, she was surprised to see
Foster Parent 1’s extensive mental health history. She stated it
was her understanding the PAFC agency knew of some of the
history but not how extensive it was. The initial home study
mentions Foster Parent 1 being hospitalized approximately 20
times in the past due to mental health. She reviewed Foster
Parent 1 & 2’s MISACWIS provider record and didn’t see any of
the records and there was no other mention in the home study.
Included in the home study were a couple health evaluations that
covered the past 2 years but did not go back further. It also
mentioned her having a history of auditory hallucinations.
PAFC AW stated she did not believe Youth A, B and C were at
imminent risk while placed in Foster Parent 1 & 2’s home but there
was a more constant underlying concern. She stated at the time,
she did not believe Youth A, B and C were being abused but this
concern was elevated during Foster Parent 1’s most recent
hospitalization in August 2023. After Youth A, B and C were
placed elsewhere, the PAFC agency was no longer concerned
regarding the number of medical appointments Foster Parent 1 &
2 took them to.
PAFC AW stated there were internal discussions regarding
concerns about the number of medical appointments and there
were questions about whether it was Munchausen. She stated
While speaking to medical offices to confirm the number of
appointments the children attended, PAFC FC Supervisor 1
inquired if there were concerns regarding how many appointments
the children attended. She stated Cherry Health and Spectrum
use different systems so they most likely were not able to see
appointments the children had attended with the other provider
and did not report any concerns. Once the children were moved to
another placement and it was determined by the new medical
providers Youth A, B and C did not have all of the medical needs
Foster Parent 1 & 2 indicated they had, the agency realized the
extent of the concerns.
PAFC Foster Care Supervisor 1 (PAFC FC Supervisor 1) was
interviewed via telephone on July 3, 2024. She stated she was
assigned as the foster care supervisor from 9/13/2021 until
5/20/2022 and then PAFC FC Supervisor 2 was the primary foster
care supervisor while she was on maternity leave. She came back
5

from maternity leave and was reassigned as the foster care
supervisor on 3/4/2023. After termination of parental rights had
occurred, her assignment ended on 9/5/2023. When she was
reassigned to the case in March 2024 a transfer meeting was held
that included adoption staff. The purpose of the meeting was to
provide up to date case information. PAFC FC Supervisor 2
mentioned Foster Parent 1 & 2 had been difficult to work with. At
the beginning of April 2024 FCW brought up some concerns
during supervision. Youth B, who was 3 years old at the time, was
taken to a psychiatrist at Cherry Health on 4/7/2023 and the
psychiatrist wanted to prescribe him with caffeine. She sought
input from the agency’s behavioral health team and asked FCW to
try and get more information regarding why Youth B was referred
to a psychiatrist and how many appointments he has had since
this was the first they had heard of him going to a psychiatrist. The
agency obtained the records from the psychiatrist and learned this
was the first time Youth B had met with a psychiatrist and the
psychiatrist had diagnosed him with Reactive Attachment Disorder
(RAD) in addition to prescribing him caffeine. PAFC FC
Supervisor 1 stated this raised red flags and the agency requested
a second opinion, but Cherry Health did not agree. A follow up
appointment was scheduled that included PAFC FCW and PAFC
AW along with Foster Parent 1 & 2. The appointment did not go
well. Caseworkers were questioned by the psychiatrist as well as
Foster Parents 1 & 2 regarding why they were there, why they
were questioning the diagnosis of RAD and why they were not
willing to consent to caffeine pills. PAFC FC Supervisor 1 stated
during the time from the first appointment with the psychiatrist and
the second appointment, Foster Parents 1 & 2 sent multiple text
messages to PAFC FCW and PAFC AW indicating the kids were
sick and needed to be taken to the doctor. She stated this was
occurring so often that it raised red flags.
At that point the agency contacted Cherry Health and inquired
how often Foster Parents 1 & 2 were taking Youth A, B and C to
the doctor and asked how many appointments have occurred. The
agency was provided the information on 4/26/2023 when PAFC
AW was granted access to the children’s patient portal through
Cherry Health. PAFC AW provided all the appointments she
gathered in the patient portal on 5/4/2023. PAFC FC Supervisor 1
went through and verified the appointments took place because
sometimes if a call is placed to a doctor with a question, it can be
listed as an appointment. Once the appointments were verified a
support specialist requested all the documentation from the
medical providers. PAFC FC Supervisor 1 clarified there had been
situations where one or more of the youth were taken to the doctor
6

for an ear infection and Foster Parents 1 & 2 wanted to take them
back the following day without allowing time for the medication to
work. Based on the concerns, the agency scheduled a Family
Team Meeting (FTM) in May 2023 with Foster Parents 1 & 2,
health care liaison, licensing worker and supervisor from DHHS
licensing, to discuss the concerns regarding the number of
medical appointments the children were taken to. A verbal safety
plan was developed where Foster Parent 1 & 2 were told to notify
the agency in a timely manner of any appointments for the
children so someone from the agency could attend. From that
point on Foster Parent 1 & 2 notified the agency of each
appointment they were scheduling.
Additional concerns came up after PAFC AW received the initial
home study and other documents she received as part of her
adoption assessment. The agency scheduled a meeting with
DHHS licensing on 5/4/2023 and with the Department of Child
Welfare Licensing (DCWL) on 5/12/2023 to review concerns with
Foster Parent 1. Complex case reviews included the foster care
worker, foster care supervisor, any internal service providers, and
clinical team (Family Preservation Team and Behavioral Health
Team) from the PAFC agency. Complex case reviews were held
on a biweekly basis. The participants from the complex case
reviews were concerned with Munchausen but did not know what
avenue to take since no one at the PAFC agency was qualified to
make that diagnosis. This was the point when they requested
meetings with the DHHS licensing team and DCWL.
PAFC FC Supervisor 1 stated there were over 130 appointments
that Foster Parents 1 & 2 did not notify the agency of. She stated
DHHS licensing questioned why they didn’t bring the concerns to
their attention sooner. She stated once they had information and
documentation to back up their concerns, they brought it to the
attention of DHHS licensing. PAFC FC Supervisor 1 stated she
had a couple of meetings with PAFC FC Supervisor 2 and
inquired if she had any concerns while she was on the case. She
stated there were concerns regarding the number of appointments
as well as Foster Parents 1 & 2 frequently asking to switch
services. Foster Parents 1 & 2 did not want any services through
PAFC.
When PAFC FC Supervisor 1 was assigned, she was informed
during the case transfer meeting that Foster Parents 1 & 2 had
been difficult to work with. They were stressed and overwhelmed,
did not like the direction the PAFC agency was going with the
case, the length of time it took for parental rights to be terminated
7

and Biological Mother still had to provide consent prior to
termination. After March 2023 things seemed to improve slightly
but it was still a struggle regarding communication and obtaining
requested information and documentation. Foster Parents 1 & 2
reported Youth A, B and C had all sorts of medical issues and
behavioral concerns, specifically Youth A, B and C were not
attaching appropriately. In addition, Foster Parents 1 & 2 stated
Youth A, B and C should not be placed together and specifically
had stated Youth B needed to be placed elsewhere if the agency
decided not to separate all of them. PAFC FC Supervisor 1, PAFC
FCW, and the adoption team started to dig a little deeper and
realized Foster Parents 1 & 2 were not actively working with the
service providers in the home. The service providers working with
them reported Youth A, B and C are bonded and they did not
share the same concerns regarding behaviors and attachment.
Youth A, B and C’s daycare provider did not have any of the
concerns that Foster Parents 1 & 2 were reporting. It raised the
level of concern because none of the service providers were
seeing any of the behaviors or concerns Foster Parents 1 & 2
were reporting.
PAFC FC Supervisor 1 stated Foster Parents 1 & 2 made it
difficult to conduct monthly home visits to verify wellbeing. She
stated this was the most difficult piece and the agency tried to
accommodate them as much as possible. For example, enhanced
foster care (EFC) was doing weekly home visits so the PAFC
FCW would ask to do a visit at the same time and Foster Parents
1 & 2 would respond by saying that is too many people in the
home. The attachment therapist was required to meet weekly but
due to Foster Parents 1 & 2 constantly rescheduling she was only
able to conduct biweekly visits or sometimes had to do virtual
visits despite Youth A, B and C needing the service. PAFC FC
Supervisor 1 again stated although the agency had concerns, they
were not concerned with imminent risk and they were not qualified
to make a determination regarding Munchausen by Proxy.
PAFC Foster Care Program Manager (PAFC FC PM) was
interviewed via telephone on July 3, 2024. She could not recall
when concerns were initially brought to her attention regarding
Youth A, B and C while placed with Foster Parents 1 & 2.
Concerns started to arise regarding the number of medical
appointments Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C were going to. The
agency was not aware of the majority of the appointments at the
time they were occurring. Once they were able to gather some
information and documentation after parental rights were
8

terminated and adoption became involved, they became
concerned. At the same time, they did not have any medical
professionals who had expressed those concerns. The agency
had concerns regarding the number of appointments. After the
children were removed the agency was able to obtain a clearer
picture of the amount and type of appointments they had been
taken too. They were taken to different medical professionals who
did not feel some of the medical needs reported by Foster Parents
1 & 2 and previous medical professionals were accurate. PAFC
FC PM stated she did not have her notes in front of her to provide
more detailed examples, but she recalled one youth having a RAD
diagnosis and that concern had never been previously reported
and another instance of one youth being seen by an allergy
specialist and had not been diagnosed with any allergy.
PAFC FC PM stated Foster Care Review Board became involved
after the children were in September 2023 due to Foster Parent 1
& 2 filing an appeal. She stated the agency contacted MCI to
discuss concerns and their desire to move the children but could
not recall when those interactions started. Foster Care Review
Board and MCI both agreed it was in the children’s best interests
to move to a different placement.
PAFC FC PM stated the agency had concerns but did not feel the
concerns rose to the level of Children’s Protective Services (CPS)
involvement. Youth A, B and C were attending appointments and
none of the providers reported they were going too often or being
seen for things they shouldn’t be. The idea was to reassess after
Youth A, B and C were moved and able to be seen by other
providers to see if the previous medical concerns were still
present.
PAFC Foster Care Worker (PAFC FCW) was interviewed via
Teams on July 10, 2024. She stated she was assigned to the
case from March 2023 until approximately March or April 2024.
She stated she was given an update on the case when she was
initially assigned and was told about concerns regarding Foster
Parent 1 & 2 doing things they were asked by the agency not to
do. One example she provided was Foster Parent 1 & 2 were told
not to take Youth B to a psychiatrist and did anyway. The agency
received a coordination form for Youth B’s monthly early childhood
attachment therapy at the agency and it was noted that he had
attended a psychiatric appointment. At that point, PAFC FCW and
PAFC AW called the office and found they had another
appointment scheduled for him. She stated this was the first red
flag that there were appointments the agency wasn’t aware of.
9

They were concerned why Youth B was seeing a child psychiatrist
as he was only 3 years old. Foster Parents 1 & 2 were not in
agreement with the agency’s concern and informed the agency
they could attend the follow up appointment and expressed their
concerns. PAFC FCW and PAFC AW attended the appointment
on 4/7/2023 and expressed their concerns with the child
psychiatrist. The psychiatrist was diagnosing Youth A with
Reactive Attachment Disorder (RAD) and wanted to prescribe a
caffeine pill and Benadryl. PAFC FCW stated the child psychiatrist
was not in agreement with the agency’s concerns. Due to COVID
restrictions, only one foster parent was allowed back so Foster
Parent 1 was present. PAFC FCW stated Foster Parent 1 was
presenting as though she was going to have an anxiety or panic
attack due to the agency not agreeing with the recommendations.
The child psychiatrist wrote in her report the foster care agency
wasn’t complying with medical direction.
There were no concerns regarding the number of appointments
Youth A, B and C were going to until the agency gained access to
My Chart and saw all of the appointments they went to. Not long
after the appointment with the psychiatrist the agency had a
discussion regarding efforts to locate medical records to see
where and how many appointments Youth A, B and C had been
to, since it was clear the agency was not notified of all of them or
the majority of them. Some of the reasons Youth A, B and C were
seen were due to behavioral and medical concerns reported by
Foster Parents 1 & 2. The agency had enhanced foster care and
an early childhood attachment therapist going to the home. Foster
Parents 1 & 2 reported Youth A was throwing up every time she
was eating. The service providers in the home had not reported
those concerns. Relative visits were also occurring, and the
agency asked if they observed any concerns, and they were not
seeing the same things. There was a large inconsistency with
what was being reported and what had been observed. The
agency began to question what observations Foster Parents 1 & 2
were reporting to medical providers.
PAFC FCW stated she became concerned regarding Foster
Parent 1’s mental health due to her behavior at the psychiatric
appointment. The initial disagreement with Youth B’s treatment
plan and not agreeing with a RAD diagnosis caused Foster Parent
1 to present some physical behaviors in response, such as
shaking, heavy breathing, rocking back and forth and putting her
hands in her hair. PAFC FCW and PAFC AW discussed the
concerns and the need to obtain Foster Parent 1’s mental health
records to gain a better understanding of the scope of her issues.
10

PAFC FCW clarified the meeting was professional and there was
no yelling, but there were different opinions, and she was visibly
upset.
PAFC FCW stated there was never a service provider or medical
provider that reported concerns regarding the number of
appointments the children were attending. She and PAFC AW
inquired with the receptionist at Cherry Health about obtaining
records for all the appointments. She stated they have attended
many appointments and would need to make a request to obtain
verifications. She stated it was somewhat conflicting because she
and PAFC AW felt strongly about their concerns but none of the
other providers agreed other than the providers at their agency.
The agency began having conversations regarding moving Youth
A, B and C between May-August 2023. They recently considered
best interests and what moving Youth A, B and C to other
placements could look like. They addressed some of the concerns
in the treatment plan and informed Foster Parents 1 & 2 if this
doesn’t work, Youth A, B and C would be moved. She clarified the
plan included notifying the agency prior to initiating any medical
appointments for the children and ensuring Foster Parent 1 was
participating in services to address her mental health. She stated
the Guardian Ad Litem (GAL) was supportive of the agency.
Foster Parents 1 & 2 agreed to the treatment plan but wouldn’t
follow through. They didn’t have proof Foster Parent 1’s mental
health was being addressed and there continued to be
appointments the agency was not notified of. After Youth A, B and
C were moved, they were seen by new medical providers, as the
agency wanted a fresh perspective. After Youth A, B and C were
assessed the relative’s presented questions from PAFC FCW
regarding specific medical diagnoses and concerns that were
previously reported by Foster Parent 1 & 2. The questions were
asked after the assessment to gain an accurate and unbiased
assessment. The appointment for each youth noted no concerns.
PAFC Foster Care Supervisor 2 (PAFC FC Supervisor 2) was
interviewed via telephone on July 17, 2024. She stated she
became assigned as the supervisor approximately 30 days prior to
the children moving to Foster Parent 1 & 2’s home, which
occurred on 5/5/2022. She initially had concerns regarding Foster
Parent 1 & 2 when she became the supervisor due to Foster
Parents 1 & 2’s excessive contact. She stated every day there
were 10-20 emails, text messages or voicemails from Foster
Parents 1 & 2 to PAFC FCW asking questions regarding topics
that were not important, but Foster Parents 1 & 2 were very
11

anxious about. For example, children’s legal father wasn’t involved
but Foster Parents 1 & 2 had heard at some point through non-
child welfare sources that legal father may be in Michigan. Foster
Parents 1 & 2 made up their minds that he was dangerous and
would find out where they lived and take Youth A, B and C. They
would also ask questions regarding topics/issues they were not
privy to know. For example, they wanted to know where biological
mother lived. They would then report concerns regarding Youth A,
B and C or ask questions regarding them. The questions didn’t
make sense in the moment, but the agency wasn’t concerned with
the questions, just the amount of daily contact. The agency asked
Foster Parents 1 & 2 to put together a weekly email with
questions, concerns or comments and the worker would respond
on Monday morning. She stated Foster Parents 1 & 2 didn’t follow
the guidelines, so she took over the communication with them
because they were overbearing.
In spring of 2023 PAFC FC Supervisor 2 began having concerns
regarding the number of appointments the children were
attending. She stated Foster Parents 1 & 2 would take Youth A, B
and C to a med center or the ER prior to notifying the agency and
it would be due to common cold symptoms. She stated she was
aware Foster Parents 1 & 2 had a higher level of anxiety and felt
this was probably the reason for taking those steps, as well as
being first time foster parents. She stated she asked for
documentation for the appointments and Foster Parents 1 & 2
would not provide them. She stated she had conversations with
them indicating they should not be taking Youth A, B and C to the
med center or ER every time they cough or sneeze. She stated
they were welcome to call their primary care physician.
PAFC FC Supervisor 2 stated Foster Parents 1 & 2 indicated
Youth A, B and C have asthma and she responded by informing
them that a diagnosis for this does not exist. PAFC FC Supervisor
2 stated they may have it but there is not a current diagnosis. She
stated she informed Foster Parents 1 & 2 that she needed to be
notified prior to taking the children to a medical appointment and
when an appointment occurred, she wanted paperwork. PAFC FC
Supervisor 2 stated this did not happen. She stated they were
very pushy to have the children obtain COVID shots and biological
mother did not agree and would not consent. Foster Parents 1 & 2
attempted to bully the GAL to have the shots court ordered and it
was brought up to the agency several times. Foster Parents 1 & 2
wanted to address the issue with Youth A, B and C’s biological
mother. Biological Mother did consent, but the behavior was
concerning.
12

When she did her last home visit with them, she requested all the
medical documentation for Youth A, B and C. She stated she had
asked multiple times in the past. She stated Foster Parents 1 & 2
stated they have all the documents in a drawer in their home, but
they were not organized so they would not provide them. She
stated they provided a different excuse each time for why they
wouldn’t provide the medical documentation. On one occasion
they stated, “you have access to the chart”, or “we told you about
this” or “we sent this to you”. She stated she received some
information and documentation, but it didn’t match the amount
Youth A, B and C were going. She stated during the time she was
directly involved it wasn’t an egregious number of appointments.
but as time went on the suspicions grew regarding the number of
appointments the Youth A, B and C were taken to and Foster
Parent 1 & 2 not providing medical documentation for all the
appointments the children attended. In addition, Foster Parents 1
& 2 said no to providing requested documentation from the
medical appointments to her during a home visit, the agency
agreed they needed to start investigating. She stated she
reviewed Foster Parents 1 & 2 home study which briefly mentions
the mental health concerns and all the behaviors of Foster Parent
1 & 2 she noted made sense.
She stated she never had concerns for Youth A, B and C’s
physical safety while with Foster Parents 1 & 2. She observed
Foster Parents 1 & 2 were overly concerned and attentive with
Youth A, B and C. She stated she was concerned with how their
behavior would affect Youth A, B and C long-term, particularly
Youth B. She stated they would often paint a picture that he was a
very misbehaved child who has numerous needs. She stated she
did not observe any behaviors that were above what a typical 3-
year child would display. She stated during meetings with service
providers or GAL and FTM’s they would indicate he was so
misbehaved, and they can’t get him to listen, and they aren’t sure
what to do. Some of the behaviors they discussed were witnessed
by PAFC FC Supervisor 2 and she didn’t think it was above and
beyond what a typical 3-year-old would display.
DHHS Licensing Supervisor (DHS LS) was interviewed via
Teams on July 25, 2024. He stated Foster Parent 1 and Foster
Parent 2 have been licensed through his office since April 2022
and until last fall had placement of a sibling group of 3 through a
borrowed bed placement with a PAFC agency. He stated there
were concerns regarding Foster Parents 1 & 2 calling PAFC
13

agency too much and once the case moved to adoption there
were additional concerns reported.
He stated his office opened two special investigations on Foster
Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2 based on concerns reported. The
first one, initiated on 6/20/2023 was regarding, in part, concerns
about the number of medical appointments Youth A, Youth B and
Youth C were attending and also Foster Parent 1’s mental health.
The second special investigation was initiated on 10/13/2023 due
to concerns Foster Parent 1 needed to seek inpatient
hospitalization to address mental health concerns.
DHS LS stated PAFC didn’t express any concerns when his office
reached out to the agency to include input for their 6-month
